section.title: High-level Usage Models
section.simpara: The following usage models describe the Top-level and Function recursive stimuli models, leaving the Expression and Function Expression models well under-modeled. This is because the function expressions and expressions both have a good number of states and are quite complicated. The Function and Top-level states give a good picture of the behavior of the system and are a good way of describing the system. For the Expression and Function Expression models, non-parenthesized expressions are modeled here, but these models elide parenthetical states. Even with these simpler models, only the non-error transitions are recorded for each state. This gives a concept of the non-error paths through the system, but does not allow for an adequate description of the precise usage behaviors. These models provide only the general idea of how correct usage of the system may proceed.

The tables indicating the transition probabilities from each edge are in percentages. A 0 value is actually a very small percentage, rather than a purely zero value. These transitions are given as an estimate on the most common use case of the Tweaking Tuner, who is likely to be dealing with mostly correct code. This models code as it is already commonly written and would be edited for performance purposes. Other use cases would likely have more errors in them, since the code would not be so well tested.
